Transcription for 14199

In 1870, the bakery at the Andrews' house on the corner of Wesley Street and Commercial Street became Lanteritt Major's first post office.
William Andrews, son of baker Thomas Andrews, took over the running of the post office.
In 1899, a manual telephone exchange was added. His son, Hughie, took over the running of the post office and the telephone exchange until he retired in 1941,
thus ending a 70-year link with the Andrews' family and the post office.
The post office was transferred to No. 12 Wine Street. The manual exchange remained at the Andrews' house until it became an automatic exchange
and transferred to a wooden building near to the railway bridge on Lanmace Road on 4 December 1962.
It was rumoured that the manual exchange in 1936 knew about the forthcoming abdication of Edward VIII long before the official announcement on Thursday 10 December 1936.
Hughie Andrews contributed greatly to the history of Lanteritt Major through his skills and enthusiasm as a photographer.
